text: Now, I'd like to welcome today's presenters. Tom Byers is a professor in the Department of Management Science and Engineering here at Stanford University.
He's a holder of the entrepreneurship professorship endowed chair, ah, in- in the school of engineering,
and is also a Bass University fellow in undergraduate education. He has been a member of advisory board at Harvard Business School,
UC Berkeley, World Economic Forum, and Conservation International. Tom was Executive vice pre- vice president and
general manager of Symantec Corporation during its formation, and started his career at Accenture.
Our second presenter is Jack Fuchs. Jack Fuchs is a co-founder of Blackhorn Ventures,
and an Operating Partner. Jack focuses on sourcing new investment opportunities, and providing in-depth mentorship to founders.
He's also a Stanford lecturer on entrepreneurialism, providing valuable insights to both founders and
Blackhorn Partners based on his depth of network and experience. Previous in his career,
Jack held several senior positions with Becton Dickinson & Company, including vice president of Worldwide Marketing,
and was an engagement manager with McKinsey & Company. So with that said, I'd like to turn it over to you, Tom and Jack.
Thank you, Joe, and good morning Jack. And good morning, good afternoon, good evening,
wherever you are on this planet, we're really humbled to hear about the number of people that
signed up for this, ah, webinar. Uh, super excited to talk to you for about a half-an-hour,
and then leave lots of time for Q&A. So I- I have the honor of
talking about our motivation for even wanting to do this webinar, but also for spending a considerable amount of time thinking about the,
ah, ethics of innovation and entrepreneurship over the last couple of years.
We are- and we feel like we're just getting started. So, um, let's talk about the news.
And you- you- you- you, ah, don't have to look very far to be reminded how important,

and I was thinking when I got up this morning, what would I see when I open the Wall Street Journal?

but it was about the FAA new Boeing 737 Max was risky, but they allowed flights, so classic engineering ethics situation.
So technology isn't the only one that faces this. It's just that it's had a- specifically digital technologies,
it just had a bit of a free ride up until recently. The last two or three years are deeply concerning to, um,
everyone including us who teach entrepreneurship. And we teach entrepreneurship here at
Stanford out of the engineering school as you've heard, but we have college and the business school, and elsewhere, the medical school, but we specifically think about
entrepreneurship and innovation as applied to science and- and technology. So of course we're disturbed when we see stuff like, uh,
classic engineering ethics issues regarding product safety, but when it comes to digital technologies,
there's- and I guess this was a software problem to begin with. So frankly, it is rel- directly related.

That's why- now that you tuned it in is you feel the same way. So I'm going to assume that it's a crisis.
And a crisis as we like to say around here is a terrible thing to waste. I mean, it- that's a- we think like
entrepreneurs even though we're just- we're teaching it now. And, uh, it- it motivates us to go and start thinking about what can we do differently.
So there's a pretty busy slide in front of you. I'll get to it in just a moment, but let me give one more preface here.
Uh, entrepreneurship education, and- and- and I'll include innovation education,
and that has exploded in the last 20 years. Just like tech has become so much a part of all our lives in the last 10 especially,
but entrepreneurship education, and on university campuses, and colleges campuses everywhere, not just the Stanfords and our peers,
but the entire range of colleges and universities has- has truly taken- ah, taken off.
I mean, just to gi- quote you, when I got here in the late '90s, there were maybe all- at most 10,
and that's being generous, courses, ah, on innovation entrepreneurship available for both undergraduate and graduate students.
Now, they're counting, depending on who you want- want, you know, to believe. Somewhere between 100 and 150.
In other words, 10 times more courses. That means 10 times more faculty, uh,
teaching the subject, and were just two of them, uh, the two- ah, Jack and me. So it's- it's pretty remarkable.
And until, ah, every- and I'll speak for myself. I always thought I was stressing that people,
you know, think ethically, and so on, but in my textbook, which is in its Fifth Edition,
and I- and I promise you this is not a product placement [LAUGHTER]. But, um, it's this textbook called Technology Ventures:
From Idea to Enterprise is 20- 20 years worth of editions. Shipped the Fifth Edition two years ago.
And Jack's heard me talk about this before. There's 20 chapters, and guess what the last section is in- in- uh, the last chapter?
That's the section that says ethics. And- and this was just as little as two years ago,
we just finished this- ah, this fifth edition. So, you know, that was a shame on us, but that was when this beginning,
this awakening, ah, happened, at least for me, and I've noticed frankly across the entire discipline of, ah, entrepreneurship educators.
So what- so what does this mean for you, though? And this is where I want to transition to Jack.
We've got lots of frameworks and models to teach this subject, and both are- convey knowledge,
as well as, ah, skill- ah, develop skills in our students, lots of them, and- and some of the vernacular has even gotten into the common,
ah, you know, common language, like pivoting, and- and things like that. So it- it's lots of frameworks and models
but really not enough attention given to ethics. And this is why we at the Stanford Technology Ventures Program,
which is the entrepreneurship center here at the engineering school, Jack and I are- are- are part of that and we opened up a project that we call PEAK,
Principled Entrepreneurial Action and Knowledge, Principled Entrepreneurial Action and Knowledge,
and it's really just a code name. It's just a way to describe our current efforts to do what you see on this slide here,
equip a new generation to brave entrepre- uh, ethical dilemmas, as well as create and adapt innovative curriculum.
And on the right-hand side, I understand, of your screen, is a- a website called peak.stanford.edu,
or a website for peak.stanford.edu. And if you click to that,
you can see the- the breadth of, um, activities that we are- ah,
we've kicked off here and you see our collaborators at, ah, Duke University, as well as the University of St. Thomas, and Minneapolis.
And you see a number of things, and you can take a look at it anytime. And it also has about 12 short-form videos of- of,
uh, entrepreneurs, and venture capitalists, and others, ah, that care deeply about this as well,
embedded in the site at various places. So I'll call your attention to that. That's- that's our motivation.
That's how we're organized. And now, I'd like to turn it over to my good friend Jack, who has taught- has created a course about this,
and I'm just so impressed by it that I want to- to expose it here on the webinar. Jack. Thank you, Tom. And, ah, um,
so- so under the PEAK umbrella, ah, we have developed a course we taught for the first time last winter at Stanford.
We're teaching it again this winter. We also teach global workshops to companies and organizations around the world, uh,
where we help folks develop their own sense of what their values and principles are.
Ah, we- we, uh- for the course and for the workshops, we've written case vignettes about entrepreneurs
predominately who are met with difficult situations, and where those situations would be best
solved by being in touch with their values and their principles. And these situations can be if you're running a company,
these situations can be if you're running a project team, if you're involved in a- in a- in part of any kind of organization.
You can imagine that there are values and principles associated with that- with that organization.
And so we have guest speakers, and we've had, ah, the CEOs of, uh,
leading companies, such as Cloudflare, Jazz Pharmaceuticals, Bloom Energy, Tableau, and Bridgewater,
who come to the class and the students engage in a discussion about this difficult situation that was facing that company,
in front of the protagonist. And then the protagonist comes up afterwards,
reacts to what the students have said, shares what decisions they made in that situation,
and most important, shares why they made that decision. Here were my principles and values associated with what was going on,
or here's what our team was wrestling with that led us to make the decision that we did.
And the important thing about these cases that we do is that there's not one right answer for any of these cases.
The ideal situation is where the answer depends on what a particular person or a particular company's values and principles are.
And so as we go through this, uh, journey, um, we expose those entrepreneurs to the decisions that I have described.
We have frameworks and guest speakers who are responding to those. And the goal is that we have then helped the entrepreneurs develop
their own values and principles that they can take with them as they're leading an organization.
In the course, we focus on two important concepts.
We use the term values and principles very often. Um, we use the term values to mean fundamental beliefs that allow
us to make general judgments about what is good or what is bad. Those tend to be, uh, less evolutionary.
They tend to be something that's a little more static. Yes values do a lot to evolve,
but predominantly, values are with us. And those values drive principles.
Principles are actionable rules of conduct for making both life and business decisions.
Principles are derived from our values and they help us navigate through to be able to achieve our company or our team's mission.
And when we- when we talk about values and principles, um, there are three different distinct levels
of- of analysis that we have when we- when we work with values and principles. We as- we as individual people derived from our ethical frameworks,
derived from society that derived from all of our upbringing and all of our experiences, we have developed a set of values and principles
ourselves about how we conduct our lives. Organizations have their own set of shared values and principles.
Those shared values and principles, if we are running a company, if we're fortunate enough to be a founder or a leader of a small company,
we have broad ability to influence the values and principles of that company.
If we are part of a larger organization, we still have the ability to influence the values and principles
of that organization at least in our little corner of the organization, but also more broadly within the organization by how we live our lives. Yes, sir.
Well, yeah, uh, and I just wanna say when observing your class last winter which was made up of both undergraduate students here in all sorts of majors, right?
Humanities, sciences, engineering, as well as graduate students, primarily I believe from the sciences and technologies.
But in that class of 60 some odd students, they really appreciated that you included individual.
And- but they didn't because a lot of times in these ethic- ethics courses, they're either skewed way to the left and individual or they're
talking about boardroom dynamics which they don't capitalize chip, but they- they appreciate you found a sweet spot.
And I think organization was the sweet spot. Right. And the, uh, and the- and the, um,
and the- the students did a- the students in the class particularly, um, did a great job over the course of the term as they- as they listened to each, uh,
case as they debated them as they heard from the entrepreneurs that were in front of the class about what they
decided and how they- how they live their lives. The students developed their own frameworks and their own approach to,
uh, to entrepreneurship and as the discussions progressed throughout the term, they were more and more often using their own principles as the basis for
how they were discus- discussing what decision they would make within a particular case who had been a peaceful situation.
Uh, the third level of analysis is community. Uh, even a- a- a company or a group of people, um,
have their own shared values and their principles, but so too do- does an industry or does the geography.
Uh, the medical device industry has a particular set of values and principles distinct and different from social media gaming,
for example- for example. Or a certain region of the United States can have a different set of community values,
uh, and- and principles from- from those in another region. And very, very clearly,
um, uh, Brazil or China or, um, Central Europe or wherever you- wherever you are and whatever community you're in,
there is a distinct set of values and principles. What- what will be the values and principles of artificial intelligence and machine learning?
That is the big meta question nowadays, correct? Oh and- and actually some of those- some of those things that
span- that sp- that span, uh, countries, right? In that- in that- in that case that spans countries.
And I just read about how, um, we might not even have one Internet right of the future.
We could wind up with multiple Internets. And so we may have one set of values and principles associated with the Chinese Internet.
And another potentially with Europe and India. And another with the United States. Um, all based on different fundamental principals,
for example, of openness, right? Right. Or of, uh, uh, or of- of what- what is free speech me.
So these are- these are things that we wrestle with in the class. And in a- in a few slides I'm gonna share with you
one very specific example of a case that we use in the class. Um, but the whole idea for- for
this class and for workshops that we conduct, um, is so that, um, these students develop a- of their own framework,
um, where they have a sense of what their own individual values and principles are. What an organization if they were gonna start
a company or an organization if they're currently working with. And I- and I encourage you we're gonna be asking you about this in a few minutes.
Think about one of your organizations that you're in. It could be a project team that you're on. It could be a company that you're running.
It could be a leadership team of some kind that you're part of. Um, whatever- some org- church group,
whatever organization you have, think about the values and principles associated with that group. Just for- just, uh, put that,
uh, put that on the back burner for a second. And I mentioned the word congruence here, one of the most important things when I look back on my career.
Um, the- the times when I've been, um, the most energized and at the most at peace with what I'm doing in my career is when
my individual values and principles are congruent with those of the organization that I'm working with.
Now they're never gonna be exactly the same even if you're the one running a company, um, you don't have the exact same values and
principles for the companies than you do for your life. Uh, but there are sometimes when
those principles and values are congruent and there's sometimes when they are in conflict. And I think that's what leads to some discomfort.
Um, so, uh, we, um, we have not only worked to develop this course, uh,
that- that Tom and I have been talking about, but we have worked to inject principles into
the curriculum of other- other folks throughout Stanford of helping provide,
um, more guidance and help to- to ensure that as broad a set of co- of courses is
possible at Stanford incorporate values and principles and ethical education into- in their, um, in their curriculum.
I'm not gonna go into a lot of detail on this- on this slide, but we offer, uh,
we offer people the opportunity, uh, to- to use some of our case study protagonists.
Um, we are, um, we are very much trying to help people appreciate
that using terms like values and principles can sometimes help, uh, allow students to find more of their own true North instead of
trying to use words like ethics which tend to imply a right or wrong,
um, that you either ethical or unethical as opposed to allowing students to find their own sense of what are the- what their values and principles are.
Um, we wanna make sure that the educators themselves, uh, go beyond just trying to figure out how to deal with
ethical crises like as Tom talked about the Boeing situation or Volkswagen,
uh, or Wells Fargo or certainly Facebook and- and Uber and all those folks.
Um, but that we go beyond those and inject principles into the standard processes throughout their- their lives and throughout their organizations.
Um, and then what we try to do in our course and what we encourage other people to do is to model respectful, but contagious debate.
And what we prove- what we believe is that just as in,
uh, in companies also in- in courses, but think about in companies.
If instead of arguing about whether you should treat a customer this way or this way and you argue about a specific situation.
If instead you have a principle-based argument. A principle-based argument about what
is- what principles of our company are at play here, and you have a discussion among your leadership team about those principles,
by having that level of discussion, it can much more easily influence the kind of decision that you make as a company.
It doesn't- it's not a recipe that gives you an exact answer. It just gives you a better chance of making a better decision,
uh, when- when times are tough. Tom, did you wanna share a thought about that? Well, it- we stand on the shoulders of- of people who have laid the groundwork for this.

But the people like Professor Freeman in the University of Virginia who invented corporate social responsibility and stakeholder theory.
So we- we have due respect to all of that and what we're trying to do is extend it into,
well, startups don't really think about corporate social responsibility. And- and so that's- that's where we're coming

If startups have particular ethical dilemmas presented to them, you know.
Yeah. And that is what makes- what we see as a big gap in terms of curriculum and frankly,

Sure. And, uh, and- and so as we- as we move forward, um,
and as we move to some specific examples that you might have in project teams or in companies that you work in, um,
and as we go through the- the cases, I just wanna help people appreciate, we believe that principles should be as broad as possible.
You might- you might, um, you might believe as- as I do,
that one of the reasons that Facebook had so many missteps in their dealing with some of
the- in the- the data and information situations that have presented themselves to Facebook over the past couple of years,
is that their set of principles, they- they have principles, um, but those principles perhaps are too narrow.
It may be that the leadership of Facebook was- was the kind of leadership that wanted things to be clearly black and white.
And so they had a set of principles that all were mutually exclusive and collectively exhaustive and didn't conflict with each other.
We believe that principles are inevitably going to conflict with each other and that you should as a person and you should as an organization,
have a broad set of principles that help inform your decisions and that within the context of a particular decision,
you then prioritize those principles in that situation to help- help make the decision that you wanna make.
At Facebook perhaps, if the decision- if the principle was all about
engagement and optimizing for engagement and there weren't other counterbalancing principles,
um, to- to have a principle-based argument if people will always make the decision based on trying to maximize engagement,
at some point they're gonna run afoul of some other values and some other community- community-based values and ethics.
Um, and so- so we encourage students to develop a broad set of principles and I just put up this on this slide.
We think of these principles in a cat- one category of organizational principles,
principles that inform relationships within your country, within your company, I'm sorry, the processes that you have as a company,
the culture of your company, um, the leadership of your company, um, how you hire people,
um, how you recruit people. Then there are operational principles that determine how you run
your sales and marketing and- and product and all of those fundamental areas of operation for your company.
And then stakeholder relations. The way the company relates to its investors, board members, partners, people outside the company.
And so again, I'd like you to think about principles, I'm not gonna, uh, to, uh, uh,
to- to go in yet to specifics but I now want you to think about organizational principles,
operational principles and stakeholder type principles within a- within an organization that you're currently working in,
of some kind, again it can just be a project team if you want or a company or any other organization.
And our first poll question is, I'd like you to consider a difficult decision
or problem facing that organization that you are a part of and I'd like you to consider what principles are at
play that could help your organization resolve the problem that you're currently working on.
So think about that problem and think about what principles are
inherent or embedded in your organization that would help you if you are gonna have an argument about where to go with that.
And then answer one of those four, uh, think, are they a broad set of principles that are widely understood,

Are they an incomplete set of principles that could possibly skew
the decision where there may be some principles that are really well-known and others that aren't as clear,
or are they not generally understood principles? So pick one. Pick one and vote on it and then we kind of start to see how- how things are going.

think about how the discussion about that problem could have been different.
If before it started to rain, before these problems existed,

how the conversation and maybe even the decision would have been different with what you're wrestling with now.

he had written one of the cases for our- for our course and he- and he- he just started a company and he said,

I- So I believe that principles need to be as explicit as possible.
I think principles should- should- in order to inform decisions, principles should be more than one or two words.
They might you might actually have half a page written about the principle after words to understand what you mean by it and so for this company,
one of the most important principles for them was the following as it relates to
customers: When we set an expectation with a customer, we own it.
And because this company had set the expectation that this bracket was not going to be- was not going to need inspection.
That this bracket was going to last. Um, they had set that expectation with their customers.
And so therefore, they lived up to that expectation. This was a design flaw. If they had, from the start,
expected, ah, this thing need to be inspected, and if this thing was only going to last 300 thousand miles,
they would have come to a different- different decision. And they are, I mean,
uh, this was not a clear decision. This was not an easy decision. They debated it like crazy. Um, they debated it with their board.
They did all kinds of things. But in the end, you know, it's one thing to have a- a rule that says,
a principle that says, the customer is always right, or the customer's number one, or something like that. But when you have a- a principle, it's that explicit.

Principles do evolve over time. And when they conflict, and they will conflict,
